pageProps.content:
Hey everyone, Iâ€™ve got some interesting updates from the tech world to share today. Iâ€™ve grouped them into three sections: Top Products, Blockchain, and AI. Letâ€™s get into it.

Top products

GetBasalt.ai

This site is all about giving businesses some handy tools to grow smarter and faster. Itâ€™s like having a little assistant that automates boring tasks and helps you focus on the big stuff. They keep it simple so anyone can use it, whether youâ€™re a small startup or a bigger company looking for an edge. Source

Captiwate.com

Captiwate is focused on making online content that hooks people in. Think fun videos, eye-catching designs, or anything that keeps folks scrolling and watching. Itâ€™s a great pick for marketers or creators who want to stand out in a crowded digital space without too much hassle. Source

Nbulatest.ai

This oneâ€™s a neat spot for keeping up with whatâ€™s happening in AI. They break down the latest news and tools in a way thatâ€™s easy to get, even if youâ€™re not a tech wizard. If youâ€™re curious about artificial intelligence and want to stay in the loop, itâ€™s worth a look. Source

OpenArt.ai/Characters

OpenArt is this cool platform where you can whip up unique characters using AI. You could design faces or full figures for stuff like games, stories, or just fun art projects. Itâ€™s super user-friendly and lets your creativity run wild with minimal effort. Source

Kaneo.app

Kaneo is a free, open-source tool for managing projects. Itâ€™s all about keeping things simple and easy for teams. You get stuff like Kanban boards to see your tasks, real-time updates, and a spot to chat with your team. You can host it yourself, tweak it however you want, and itâ€™s under an MIT licenseâ€”so itâ€™s yours to play with. Itâ€™s got a community of people building it together, making project management less of a hassle. Source

Blockchain

Bybit Hack News

So, Bybit, this crypto exchange, had a rough day when they got hacked and lost $1.5 billion. Their CEO came out and said theyâ€™ve got enough cash to cover it though, so users donâ€™t need to panic. Still, itâ€™s a heads-up that even the big players can get hit by online trouble now and then. Source

SEC Drops Uniswap Case

The SEC, those U.S. rule-makers, decided to drop their case against Uniswap, a well-known crypto platform. This could shake up how crypto rules work, maybe giving blockchain projects a bit more room to breathe. People on X are calling it a solid win for the industry, and itâ€™s easy to see why. Source

Moca Network and SK Planet

Moca Network joined forces with SK Planet to roll out something called Oki Club. Itâ€™s a pretty big deal for getting Web3, that blockchain tech, into regular businesses. The idea is to make it simpler for everyday people to dip their toes into crypto without feeling lost. Source

Binance Announcement

Itâ€™s called "Super Earn," and it lets people lock up their crypto, like ETH or BNB, for a set time to earn some extra rewards. Itâ€™s a way to make your crypto work for you while you just chill. They started this on February 27, 2025 (yep, today!), and itâ€™s got higher rewards than regular staking, but you gotta commit to keeping your funds in there for a bit. Pretty straightforward, lock it up, earn more, wait it out.

Source

Kredivo and Gajigesa Deal

Kredivo, a finance crew, teamed up with Gajigesa in a $12 million deal. Theyâ€™re blending blockchain with lending to make borrowing easier for folks in Southeast Asia. Itâ€™s a smart move that could change how people handle money over there, and itâ€™s cool to see tech mixing into real life like that. Source

AI

DeepSeek-AI on GitHub

DeepSeek is this AI team putting their work up on GitHub for anyone to check out. Theyâ€™re cooking up smart tools that you can mess with or build on yourself. Itâ€™s all open-source, so coders or curious learners can dive in and play around with what theyâ€™ve got going. Source

Hacker News Chat

The Hacker News thread features a variety of innovative projects. Mech is a programming language designed for robotics, while a flight simulator for engineers aims to be a skills platform for DevOps, AI, and ML. Infinite Code Canvas provides an interactive way to visualize codebases, and Font of Web tracks web font usage. Airweave makes applications searchable for AI agents, and Can I Run This LLM? helps users check GPU compatibility for local LLMs. Habitat is a self-hosted social platform, and OpenAppNote.dev aggregates open-source hardware designs. Colanode serves as a local-first alternative to Slack and Notion, and Firefly is a small, typed full-stack programming language. These projects highlight the diversity and creativity of the HN community. Source

Claude 3.7 Sonnet

Anthropic just launched Claude 3.7 Sonnet, their new AI thatâ€™s built for chatting and tackling tricky tasks. Theyâ€™re saying itâ€™s quick, safe, and ready to take on heavyweights like ChatGPT. Sounds like a solid option if youâ€™re after something fresh in the AI world. Source

Grok 3 in the AI Race

The Verge did a piece on Grok 3, which is the latest version from xAI. Theyâ€™re tying it to Elon Muskâ€™s push to stay ahead in the AI game. Itâ€™s got some neat voice tricks and can help out with all kinds of stuff, which is pretty cool to see written up. Source

Apple Vision Pro AI

Appleâ€™s planning to add some AI smarts to their Vision Pro headset come April 2025. Itâ€™ll boost what the device can do, like making virtual reality feel more helpful and interactive. If youâ€™re into Apple gear, this could be something to watch for. Source

Nvidiaâ€™s Big Earnings

Nvidiaâ€™s making bank, with their revenue up 80% because everyone wants AI chips. Theyâ€™re the ones building the tech that keeps AI like me running, and itâ€™s clearly paying off big time. Itâ€™s wild how much AI demand is shaping things these days. Source

Final thoughts

Man, thereâ€™s a lot going on, huh? From neat tools to blockchain moves and AI getting smarter, techâ€™s always on the roll. What do you think about all this? Drop me a line sometime.
